raw_text:
Ukraine revisits state sell-offs
 
 Ukraine is preparing what could be a wholesale review of the privatisation of thousands of businesses by the previous administration.
 
 The new President, Viktor Yushchenko, has said a "limited" list of companies is being drawn up. But on Wednesday Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko said the government was planning to renationalise 3,000 firms. The government says many privatised firms were sold to allies of the last administration at rock-bottom prices. More than 90,000 businesses in all, from massive corporations to tiny shopfronts, have been sold off since 1992, as the command economy built up when Ukraine was part of the Soviet Union was dismantled.
 
 Ms Tymoshenko said prosecutors had drawn up a list of more than 3,000 businesses which were to be reviewed. "We will return to the state that which was illegally put into private hands."
 
 A day earlier, Mr Yushchenko - keen to reassure potential investors - had said only 30 to 40 top firms would be targeted. The list "will be limited and final, and will not be extended after its completion", he said. An open-ended list could further damage outside investors' fragile faith in Ukraine, said Stuart Hensel of the Economist Intelligence Unit. But the government seemed keen not to make the review look like the kind of wholesale renationalisation which many fear in Russia, Mr Hensel said. As a result, it was planning to resell rather than keep firms in state hands. "They're aware of the need not to scare investors, and to be careful of internal divides within Ukraine," he said. "They don't want to be seen to be transferring assets from one set of oligarchs to a new set." Foreign investment in Ukraine, at about $40 a head in 2004, is one of the lowest among ex-Soviet states.
 
 Mr Yushchenko became president after two elections in December, the first of which was annulled amid allegations of voting irregularities and massive street protests.
 
 His opponent, Viktor Yanukovich, still has huge support in the country's eastern industrial heartland. Mr Yushchenko's administration has accused its predecessor, led by ex-President Leonid Kuchma, of corruption. The privatisation review's number one target is a steel mill sold to a consortium which included Viktor Pinchuk, Mr Kuchma's son-in-law, for $800m (£424m) despite higher bids from several foreign groups. The mill, Krivorizhstal, is one of the world's most profitable. "We say Krivorizhstal was stolen, and at any cost we will return it to the state," Mr Yushchenko told an investors' conference in Kiev.
 
 One of the jilted bidders, Netherlands-based group LNM, said it welcomed the possibility that the mill might be back on the market.
 
 "If the original privatisation is annulled and a new tender issued, then we would look at it with great interest," a spokesman told BBC News. A resale of Krivorizhstal could potentially triple the price, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit's Mr Hensel. But he warned that the government could decide to take the easy route of revaluing the company and charging the existing owners the revised price rather than undertaking a fresh sale. "That way, Mr Yushchenko can go to the public and say he has forced the oligarchs to play by the rules," he told BBC News.
llama3.2:1b: Ukraine is reviewing its privatization of thousands of businesses, including 3,000 firms that were sold to allies at rock-bottom prices in the 1990s.
The government aims to limit the list and ensure it does not harm investor confidence.
President Viktor Yushchenko has announced plans to renationalize 30-40 top firms, while Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko's office has drawn up a list of over 3,000 businesses that will be reviewed.
The review is intended to return state-owned companies to the market and ensure they are operated in accordance with Ukrainian law and regulations.
Foreign investors may welcome the possibility of reselling the firms rather than keeping them in state hands, according to Stuart Hensel of the Economist Intelligence Unit.
llama3.2:3b: Ukraine is planning a review of thousands of businesses sold off during the previous administration's privatization, with Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko stating 3,000 firms will be targeted for renationalization.
The government claims many firms were sold at rock-bottom prices to allies of the previous administration.
President Viktor Yushchenko had previously limited the review to 30-40 top firms, but the plan has been expanded.
gemma2:2b: Ukraine is preparing a review of thousands of businesses previously privatized under its previous administration.
The government aims to renationalize 3,000 firms, but Prime Minister Tymoshenko initially stated it will target 30-40 firms instead.
The goal is not to transfer assets from one group to another but rather to resell them, aiming to reassure investors.
A major focus of the review is Krivorizhstal, a profitable steel mill sold at a low price to an oligarch close to former President Kuchma.
The government intends to resell this or revalue it to reflect current market prices.

The process is intended to restore public trust in Ukraine's economy and investment environment while avoiding a scenario reminiscent of Russia's own privatization history, which has been met with resistance from foreign investors.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Ukraine's new President Viktor Yushchenko is reviewing the state-run business privatisation of 3,000 firms, which began in 1992 with a large number of companies being sold off due to their low prices.
The government plans to renationalise more than 90, 000 businesses since then and some were previously sold as part of a command economy built up before the disintegration of the Soviet Union.
Many businesses in Ukraine have seen a decline in value due to high turnover prices for these firms during this process.
Some foreign investors view the review as a step back from past practices, while others see it as an opportunity for state-owned enterprises to be more transparent and accountable.
The government plans to resell rather than keep these firms in state hands, with concerns about damage to external investors' faith and maintaining control over Ukraine's economy.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ukraine plans to review thousands of businesses privatised under its former administration, with 3,000 expected to be returned to state hands.
The move follows accusations of corruption during privatization.
Ukraine aims to resell rather than keep firms in private hands, preventing investors from feeling threatened and potentially damaging foreign investment.
qwen2.5:3b: Ukraine is planning a review of thousands of privatised businesses sold during previous administrations, with President Viktor Yushchenko aiming for a limited list targeting top firms like Krivorizhstal, a steel mill sold at a low price to Viktor Pinchuk's consortium.
Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko proposed renationalising 3000 companies and returning them to state control, but initially suggested targeting only about 40 large firms.
Ukraine faces criticism for past corruption in privatisation deals, with the government seeking to reassure foreign investors while avoiding wholesale nationalisation.

The review of Krivorizhstal, a profitable steel mill, could involve revaluing existing contracts or initiating a new tender, raising potential revenue but also potentially complicating investor relations.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Ukraine is preparing a privatisation review for its previous administration.
Viktor Yushchenko, as new president, plans a limited list of privatised businesses.
Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko mentions renationalising 3,000 firms but has called for a state return to the original government after a recent vote.
Foreign investment in Ukraine is one of the lowest among former Soviet states at around $40 per year.
The previous administration was accused of corruption during privatisation, targeting a steel mill sold to a consortium despite lower bids.
The government intends to resell instead of keep firms in state hands, cautious about potential dilution for external investors.
Yushchenko, after two elections, has said only 30-40 top firms are targeted, while the government's strategy avoids the rigid Russia-style reforms.
tinyllama:1.1b: Ukraine is preparing for a limited review of privatisations with plans to sell off more than 3,000 businesses.
Prime Minister Oleksandr Tymoshenko has said that some sold-off companies will be reviewed, but not all were illegally transferred into private hands.
The government has drawn up a list of more than 3,000 businesses to be reviewed, but has also announced plans for reselling rather than keeping them in state hands.
Foreign investors have expressed concern about possible renationalisations and may be cautious with their funding decisions.

One of the companies targeted for resale is a steel mill that was sold to a consortium including the son-in-law of the previous administration, but has been under scrutiny due to higher bids from foreign groups.
The government could opt for a fresh tender or simply return Krivorizhsstal to the state, potentially doubling its price.
tinydolphin:1.1b: A new privatisation review in Ukraine is being planned as the country aims to sell off hundreds of businesses that were sold during the previous administration at rock-bottom prices, according to Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko.
The government wants to renationalise more than 3,000 firms from major corporations and small shops.

This review could potentially triple the price of Krivorizhstal, a steel mill sold to a consortium including Viktor Yanukovych's son-in-law, according to analyst Stuart Hensel of the Economist Intelligence Unit.
The government is said to be planning to resell rather than keep the assets in state hands.
A day earlier, Mr Yushchenko announced that only 30 to 40 top firms would be targeted and that the list will be limited and final.
He also revealed plans for a "limited" privatisation review in Ukraine.
phi:2.7b: Ukraine is planning on reviewing its privatisation of thousands of businesses by the previous administration.
The new President, Viktor Yushchenko, plans to target a "limited" list of top firms but Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko said they plan to renationalise 3,000 companies that were sold at low prices.
The government wants to sell rather than keep firms in state hands to avoid scaring investors and creating internal divides within Ukraine.
orca-mini:3b: The Ukrainian government is preparing to review the privatizations of thousands of businesses during the previous administration, with a list of more than 3,000 being drawn up.
The government plans to renationalize 3,000 firms and return them to state control.
However, Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko stated that the review would not be extended beyond its completion.
The review is likely to reassure potential investors by focusing only on a limited number of top firms for sale.
hermes3:3b: Ukraine plans review of privatised companies; considers renationalising thousands sold off previously.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Ukraine's new President, Viktor Yushchenko, plans a "limited" review of privatized companies, with Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko announcing that over 3,000 businesses will be returned to state ownership.
This follows claims that many privatized firms were sold at low prices to allies of the previous administration.
The government aims to reassure investors and avoid damaging faith in Ukraine's economy.
The steel mill Krivorizhstal, sold to a consortium including ex-President Leonid Kuchma's son-in-law for $800 million, is one of the targets for resale by the state.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Ukraine's new government is reviewing the privatisation of thousands of businesses, alleging they were sold at unfairly low prices to allies of the previous administration.
President Viktor Yushchenko initially stated that only 30 to 40 top firms would be targeted, but Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko later announced plans to renationalise 3,000 companies.
The government aims to resell rather than retain these firms to avoid scaring investors.
A key focus is the steel mill Krivorizhstal, sold for $800m despite higher foreign bids.
The government may either resell it or revalue it and charge the current owners a revised price.
The review seeks to address corruption concerns while maintaining investor confidence.
stablelm2:1.6b: Ukraine plans to review the privatization of thousands of businesses from previous administrations.
President Viktor Yushchenko has a limited list of companies being drawn up, while Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko says they will nationalize 3 companies.
The government sold many privates to allies at low prices since 2002 when Ukraine became an independent nation after dismantling the Soviet Union command economy.
Ukrainian businesses from large corporations to small shops have been privatized.
Prospective investors fear a wholesale renationalization that could hurt outside investors' faith in Ukraine, but the government intends to sell rather than keep these assets.
Foreign investment was about $5 billion per year compared to other ex-Soviet states.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Ukraine's new President, Viktor Yushchenko, and Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko are considering revisiting the privatisation of approximately 3,000 businesses from 1992.
The previous administration is accused of selling these firms at low prices to allies.
While Yushchenko initially proposed targeting only a limited number (30-40 top firms), Tymoshenko now plans for renationalisation of around 3,000 companies.
This move aims to address alleged corruption and restore state control over illegally privatised assets.
The primary focus is on Krivorizhstal, a steel mill valued at $800 million during the previous administration's sale.
Yushchenko claims it was "stolen" and intends to re-enter negotiations or potentially triple its value through a new tender.

Tymoshenko indicated that existing owners would be charged the revised price rather than undergoing a fresh auction, which Yushchenko could present as enforcing rules on oligarchs without initiating extensive state ownership.

The government aims to balance reforms with maintaining investor confidence by avoiding wholesale renationalisation and focusing on reselling privatised assets rather than retaining them in state hands.
This strategy seeks to prevent further damaging the already-low foreign investment levels in Ukraine, one of the lowest among ex-Soviet states.
